results.title: The Firefighter, Police helicopter, Police officer
results.creator_credit: James Mann, Chris O'Rourke and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People Who Help Us”.
Shows the work done by a firefighter, by policemen who man the police helicopter and the work of a various police officers from senior sargents to motor cycle police. The duties and responsibilities of each profession and the necessary equipment and supplies required by each person in order to get the job done.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Mann, Chris O’Rourke and Victoria. Ministry of Education

results.title: Eskimo summer
results.creator_credit: Robert Young, Quentin Brown, Michael McKennirey, Richard Robinson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “People of the Seal”.
Eskimo Summer is compiled from some of the most vivid footage ever filmed of the life of the Netsilik Inuit in the Pelly Bay region of the Canadian Arctic. Together, the two films provide insight and understanding of a culture now almost vanished, as they show the incredible resourcefulness of the Netsilik (People of the Seal) who have adapted to one of the world’s harshest environments. Part 1: Eskimo Summer shows how Inuit families prepare for winter by hunting seal, birds and caribou and by fishing for Arctic Char during the exentded hours of daylight. (Award: Salerno)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Young, Quentin Brown, Michael McKennirey, Richard Robinson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Eskimo winter
results.creator_credit: Richard Robinson, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey, Brian Branston, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People of the Seal”.
The second of two co-productions by the British Broadcasting Corporation and the National Film Board of Canada, People of the Seal, Part 2: Eskimo Winter is compiled from some of the most vivid footage ever filmed of the life of the Netsilik Inuit in the Pelly Bay region of the Canadian Arctic. Together, the two films provide insight and understanding of a culture now almost vanished, as they show the incredible resourcefulness of the Netsilik (People of the Seal) who have adapted to one of the world’s harshest environments. Part 2: Eskimo Winter shows how Inuit families gather in communities on the sea ice to harpoon seal as they come up through breathing holes in the ice. Also seen is the mid-winter season, a time of intense socialising in the communal igloo, with games, contests and ceremonial activities. (Awards: Salerno; Trento) Narrated by Alexander Scourby
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Robinson, George Pearson, Michael McKennirey, Brian Branston, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada

Together, the two films provide insight and understanding of a culture now almost vanished, as they show the incredible resourcefulness of the Netsilik (People of the Seal) who have adapted to one of the world’s harshest environments. Part 2: Eskimo Winter shows how Inuit families gather in communities on the sea ice to harpoon seal as they come up through breathing holes in the ice. Also seen is the mid-winter season, a time of intense socialising in the communal igloo, with games, contests and ceremonial activities. (Awards: Salerno; Trento) Narrated by Alexander Scourby

results.title: A Family moves camp and gathers food (A)
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Filmed in May 1965 in the Desert Sandhill country of the Western Desert, the film documents a group of Aboriginal families still living their traditional way of life. Shows them moving camp, hunting and gathering.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Quandong cake
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “People of the Australian western desert”.
A woman nurses her baby daughter, then prepares an uncooked cake made by crushing and mixing in water the dried skin and flesh of the quandong fruit.

results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
A Pintubi man prepares and cooks a red kangaroo and divides it among his family. (Some scenes may offend animal rights supporters).

results.title: Making a wira
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Djunjurai locates a suitable tree from which to make a small wooden digging dish or wira. He starts on the tree trunk by using the hand chopper he had made, but after a time changes to a metal axe. The raw material for the dish is brought back to camp where he shapes it with an adze.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
